awd_titl_txt: Online Nonintrusive Identification and Monitoring of Internal Weak Points of Electro Energy Devices Using Package Surface Temperature
awd_abstract_narration:
Electro-energy devices (such as batteries) play an essential role in modern society with their wide spread applications that span various sectors such as transportation, healthcare, communication and renewable energy generation to name a few. Currently, assessing the longevity of such devices while they are in operation is an extremely challenging task. As a result, there exists a huge risk of untimely failure of such devices in critical missions and/or situations leading to safety issues and financial loss. Currently, there are no general, effective approaches to online identification of internal weak points and monitoring of the aging processes and health conditions of different electro-energy devices while in operation.  This project formulates and demonstrates new universal dynamic modeling and system identification methodologies for low-cost online identification and condition monitoring of internal weak points of electro energy devices using their package surface temperatures.  The methodologies do not intrude upon the devices or interrupt their operation.  The results of this research will enhance real-time, predictive condition awareness and improve the understanding of aging and failure mechanisms of electro energy devices, which will help in designing more reliable devices.  Enhanced condition awareness and design will greatly improve safety and reliability and reduce the cost and financial risk of using electro energy devices.  This project will provide interdisciplinary research training for graduate and undergraduate students and STEM education for K-12 school students focusing on dynamic system modeling and identification for energy systems applications.

This project will create a new dynamic modeling and system identification-based universal mathematical framework for nonintrusive online identification and condition monitoring of internal weak points of electro energy devices using their thermal signature.  The framework incorporates a new universal interpretation for the complex aging processes of internal weak points via the changes in the three-dimensional electrothermal dynamics of the devices estimated by measuring package surface temperatures.  Based on this interpretation, a new mathematical modeling approach will be developed to adaptively characterize the aging-related electrothermal dynamics of the devices via high-fidelity, physics-based modeling, automated model order reduction with quantifiable error bounds, online parameter identification for the reduced-order model, and high-order model reconstruction.  The identified parameters will contain information on locations, aging processes, and health conditions of the internal weak points and therefore can be used for condition monitoring of the electro energy devices.  The framework will be validated by computer simulation and experimental studies to identify and monitor internal weak points of power semiconductor devices.  In addition to electro energy devices, the research will provide enabling capabilities for modeling and diagnostics of other complex physical systems.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: SENSORS AND SENSOR SYSTEMS FOR CIS
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Under the support of this NSF CMMI project, the principal investigator has developed an integrated research and education program focusing on the real-time modeling and condition monitoring of electro energy devices, which have been used pervasively in residential, industrial, commercial, and military systems; and many of these applications are mission critical. To address the challenges in online monitoring the complex aging and failure mechanisms of electric energy devices, the team of this project has developed two model order reduction methods based on the Krylov subspace projection and Hankel singular value techniques for the automatic extraction of real-time, low-order, state-space thermal models with quantifiable and controllable approximation error bounds from finite element analysis-based, full-order, state-space thermal models for electro energy devices; two online parameter identification methods for the real-time state-space thermal models using the surface temperature information of the electro energy devices; online weak point identification and aging monitoring methods for semiconductor power modules based on the real-time adaptive thermal models; a multisensor data fusion method for the fault diagnosis of electro energy devices; a compressive sensing-based missing-data-tolerant fault detection method for electro energy devices; and an enhanced particle filtering method for the remaining useful life prediction of electro energy devices. The developed models and methods have been applied for the real-time modeling and condition monitoring of semiconductor power modules, lithium-ion batteries, and wind energy systems and have been validated by extensive computer simulation and experimental testing results carried out on these electro energy devices.

 

The developed models and methods represent a novel universal framework for interpreting, identifying, and online monitoring of the complex aging processes and failures of electro energy devices using nonintrusive measurements, which does not need to interrupt the device operation or require costly hardware implementation. Therefore, the developed models and methods overcome the drawbacks of the current state-of-the-art techniques to enhance the real-time and predictive condition awareness of electro energy devices. The enhanced condition awareness will greatly improve the safety and reliability and reduce the cost of the systems using electro energy devices, many of which are mission critical. The developed models and methods improved the understanding of aging and failure mechanisms of electro energy devices, which will help improve the design of the devices and make them more reliable.

 

The findings of this project have generated six peer-reviewed papers published in top-ranked journals, two peer-reviewed conference proceedings papers, and two Ph.D. dissertations. The principal investigator and graduate students worked on this project have developed seminar materials on thermal modeling, aging and failure mechanisms, and online condition monitoring of electro energy devices, such as silicon carbide metal–oxide–semiconductor field-effect transistor power modules, insulated-gate bipolar transistor power modules, rechargeable lithium-ion batteries, and wind energy systems. The seminar materials have been used for training graduate and undergraduate students and professionals. In particular, some of the project results have been disseminated by the principal investigator through a webinar organized by the IEEE Power Electronics Society. The webinar was recorded and the video is available on the IEEE Power Electronics Society website which can be accessed globally. The funding of this project has helped the development of an experimental test bed for testing thermal behavior and aging of power semiconductor devices and modules. The test bed is equipped with a complete set of data acquisition system, data analysis equipment, and control system. In addition to this project, the test bed can be used for studying various other issues of power semiconductor devices and modules. Moreover, a large amount of data on the aging and failures processes of electro energy devices has been generated from computer simulations and hardware tests conducted during this project.  The data provided excellent information resources for teaching and further research in the field.

 


Last Modified: 09/15/2021
Modified by: Wei Qiao
